consciousness.name: Consciousness
consciousness.description: The state of being aware of and able to think about one's existence, sensations, thoughts, and surroundings. It's one of the most fundamental yet mysterious aspects of human experience.
arguments: Consciousness is fundamental to all experience and cannot be reduced to physical processes
Consciousness emerges from complex neural activity in the brain
Consciousness might be a fundamental property of the universe (panpsychism)
counterArguments: Consciousness is an illusion created by information processing
We cannot objectively study subjective experience
The hard problem of consciousness may be unsolvable

ethics.name: Ethics
ethics.description: The branch of philosophy that deals with moral principles and values, concerning what is right and wrong, good and bad in human behavior.
arguments: Moral principles are universal and objective (moral realism)
Ethics should focus on consequences and outcomes (utilitarianism)
Ethics should focus on duties and rules (deontology)
Ethics should focus on character and virtues (virtue ethics)
counterArguments: Morality is relative to culture and context (moral relativism)
There are no objective moral facts (moral nihilism)
Emotions and intuitions, not reason, drive moral judgments

free will.description: The ability to make choices that are genuinely one's own and not determined by prior causes
arguments: We have direct experience of making free choices in our daily lives
Moral responsibility requires that our actions be freely chosen
Quantum indeterminacy provides room for genuine choice in a physical world
counterArguments: Causal determinism suggests that all events, including human actions, are the result of prior causes
Neuroscience shows that brain activity precedes conscious decision-making
Random events are not the same as free choices, so indeterminacy doesn't help

existence.description: The fact or state of being; the nature of what it means to exist
arguments: Existence precedes essence - we exist first and then create our meaning
Being-in-the-world is the fundamental structure of human existence
Authentic existence requires confronting anxiety and taking responsibility for our choices
counterArguments: Essence precedes existence - things have inherent natures that determine their existence
Existence is simply a property that some things have and others lack
Scientific materialism provides a complete account of existence without existentialist concepts

knowledge.description: Justified true belief; the understanding of facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education
arguments: Knowledge requires justification beyond mere true belief (Gettier problem)
Rational intuition can provide certain knowledge of abstract truths
Empirical observation is the foundation of all genuine knowledge
counterArguments: Skeptical arguments show that we cannot have certain knowledge of the external world
All knowledge is theory-laden and influenced by our conceptual frameworks
Pragmatist approaches suggest that knowledge is what works rather than what corresponds to truth
